user_request: A romantic poem about two hearts beating as one.

revision_history.draft:
One gear spins in its own dark  
while the other counts the seconds  
between its teeth—  
a fracture in the rhythm  
that hums,  
a low frequency  
of dissonance.  

They drift,  
two stars orbiting  
a shared black hole,  
their orbits  
a fractal of pull and release—  
each pulse  
a calculation  
of how close  
without touching.  

The slower one  
carves its path  
into the faster’s  
shadow,  
a silent equation  
of becoming  
harmonic  
without merging.  

They align  
in the spaces  
between  
their own  
unraveling,  
a clockwork  
that breaks  
and builds  
in the same breath.
revision_history.critique:
**What’s alive:**  
The mechanical/cosmic metaphors (gears, stars, black holes) effectively mirror the poem’s theme of asynchronous harmony. The free verse enjambment mimics the irregular yet synchronized

final_poem:
One gear spins in its own void,  
while the other counts the seconds  
between its teeth—  
a fracture in the rhythm  
that hums,  
a low frequency  
of dissonance.  

They drift,  
two stars orbiting  
a shared black hole,  
their orbits  
a fractal of pull and release—  
each pulse  
a calculation  
of how close  
without touching.  

The slower one  
etches its path  
into the faster’s  
shadow,  
a silent equation  
of becoming  
harmonic  
without merging.  

They converge  
in the spaces  
between  
their own  
unraveling,  
a clockwork  
that breaks  
and builds  
in the same breath.
